body:
I see. Well, to properly incorporate I would need to use them in the Eclipse tooling - it makes no sense to include them otherwise.

I'll start to do that, but don't expect them to be done overnight, and I might come back to this PR and comment about various things to further my understanding.

I might cherry-pick stuff and apply some minor changes if I think it fits the project better. How can I validate that I did not break the IntelliJ part?

You can't. If you leave the API intact it will work otherwise it for sure it won't. That said I should be able to make it work as it did shoehorning the eclipse code into IntelliJ in the first version.

I would suggest you have a look at my proposal of the eclipse implementation inside the IntelliJ project. I am pretty sure I messed a few things up (mostly because I couldn't find the source code) but it should give you an idea. We could do a screen share so we can discuss this if you have questions to expedite this (I am on PDT).

Hi @stefanseifert I've committed a bugfix plus all the test cases to cover the new implemented methods. Let me know if there is something I need to change.

Thanks,
Danilo

I might be able to set this up on an IntelliJ environment ( have zero experience with that ) , but the point remains that we will need to iterate on the changes until we have a final version and make sure that everything still works for both Eclipse and IntelliJ.

The only way to do this is incrementally including your changes in the Eclipse part, and any changes that we agree on should be included in the IntelliJ part as well. But expect that to take some time...

You don’t need to setup an IntelliJ environment (will take some time as I am not sure what should be included into GIT). That said the changes in the code should not affect Eclipse as all changes are separate.

So we could merge my code into a separate branch and then integrate over it until we are both happy with it.

Cheers - Andy

> On Apr 11, 2016, at 6:36 AM, Robert Munteanu notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> I might be able to set this up on an IntelliJ environment ( have zero experience with that ) , but the point remains that we will need to iterate on the changes until we have a final version and make sure that everything still works for both Eclipse and IntelliJ.
> 
> The only way to do this is incrementally including your changes in the Eclipse part, and any changes that we agree on should be included in the IntelliJ part as well. But expect that to take some time...
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub https://github.com/apache/sling/pull/130#issuecomment-208346671
Applied in f165ff241e3f7bbf81eea90e2e3032a578e34f1c, thanks for the contribution!
@visiongeist  - can you please manually close this? I referenced the wrong PR in the commit and this one needs to be closed manually
Fixed the problem in installBundle + added javadoc reference to the webconsole http api
I've merged this in r1746247
Fixed by Carsten Ziegeler
Patch applied in https://svn.apache.org/r1748819.
This one has been fixed differently. @anagarwa Can you close the PR?
@kwin IMO "if" clause is needed to check which bundle does the path (for which event is generated) belongs to.
Work done will commit to trunk

@bdelacretaz  as mentioned [here](http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/5/api/javax/servlet/ServletResponse.html#getOutputStream%28%29) "Either this method or getWriter() may be called to write the body, not both." So IMO, null test should be fine here . Moreover this is same as already done in sling [DefaultHeadServlet](https://github.com/apache/sling/blob/trunk/bundles/servlets/get/src/main/java/org/apache/sling/servlets/get/impl/DefaultHeadServlet.java#L133) . 
Please let me know if this is still a concern
Resolved.
Jenkins CI branch build which uses JDK 1.7 passes upto the point of launchpad/builder which required JDK 1.8.  Waiting for Travis to complete before comitting
Travis CI failed on JDK 7 at launchpad also. JDK 8 Ok.

@ghenzler  - can you please open a new SLING issue and add the reason for the rename there? If we keep adding stuff on top of SLING-5768 I fear we're going to lose track of the reasons for which we did the rename.
This has been applied. @ghenzler Please close.
This was applied
Should this be closed now that we applied #173 ?
I have committed this separately as svn revision 1764281

Just an idea: how about defining a more generic `FormattingFilter`?
It could:
- either dispatch to all sorts of `FormattingExtension` based on `format*` option
- or just use the [Formatter](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Formatter.html)? Like `${date @ formatter='...'}`. Unfortunately, the `format` option is already in use

hi @vladbailescu ,

thanks for your feedback, given that 'format' is already used, I think it was more complex / confusing how this can be used.

What is missing in this PR is 
1. Support for new Java8 date classes: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/articles/java/jf14-date-time-2125367.html
2. The locale is not specified in the SimpleDateFormatter constructor. This should be taken from the request by default (and passed to the SimpleDateFormatter, https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html#SimpleDateFormat(java.lang.String,%20java.util.Locale). Also there should be a possibility to overwrite that with an additional option, similar to what we have for `i18n`, https://github.com/Adobe-Marketing-Cloud/htl-spec/blob/master/SPECIFICATION.md#123-i18n.
What is also missing here is the timezone to express the date (it would default to the system default, which is not necessarily the time you want).
hi @wolfpl , great suggestion! I added the support for timezones.
Applied changes.
Fixed by @justinedelson  in 58a65af and 5204fd6. Will close this PR then.
Patch has been applied
@tmaret Can you add a comment why you closed this, because it does not seem this has been merged in the meantime (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING-3179).

@kwin indeed, thanks for noticing! The PR has not been merged, however the patch is still available in the JIRA issue if someone looks at it later
https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12610074/SLING-3179.diff
Thanks for the awesome feedback Roy, will update my source and re-submit.

You're welcome :) good idea though! Maybe another suggestion would be to create a model archive out of this, have a look at the latest slingshot example, it creates a MAR file that can be installed as one single package in the OSGi Installer:

           <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.sling</groupId>
                <artifactId>slingstart-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>1.7.0</version>
                <extensions>true</extensions>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <id>attach-prov-model</id>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>attach-slingfeature</goal>
                            <goal>attach-modelarchive</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
           </plugin>
https://github.com/apache/sling/tree/trunk/samples/slingshot
@raducotescu, can you please take a look?
@raducotescu @heervisscher, this has been fixed at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING-6102. We should probably close this.
@vladbailescu, I applied your patch but forgot to mark this PR as closed from the commit message. Could you please close the PR?
Thanks!

Thanks for the pull request. Would you creating an issue in the [Sling issue tracker](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING) so we can discuss the archetype and the need for it in more detail?

Thanks

I think adding the retry handling to the OSGiInstallerImpl (and therefore let all tasks profit from it) makes a lot more sense. See my proposal in http://www.mail-archive.com/dev@sling.apache.org/msg60947.html.

@kwin   a change to osgiInstallerImpl would be a lot more intrusive and in fact the others wouldn't benefit at all because they already endlessly retry. The issue with the exception handling in BundleUpgradeTask was that the status for the ResourceTask was set to ignore. Instead of switching for endless retry mode (like BundleInstallTask does) I "delay" for a certain amount of retries. 

Getting that to a higher level would require a significant change as statehandling is currently done within the ResourceTasks. I suggest to go for this low impact fix now and consider consolidating the Installer mechanisms and revisiting the state handling over all midterm (as  the current way this is done is quite brittle).

Ok, understood and agreed, but there is currently no call to retryHandler.scheduleRetry (like in https://github.com/apache/sling/blob/trunk/installer/factories/packages/src/main/java/org/apache/sling/installer/factory/packages/impl/PackageTransformer.java#L252). Therefore the retry is only done with the next cycle of the OSGi Installer (e.g. when a new bundle is supposed to be installed/updated). That seems to be wrong here, because it may cause a very long delay until the bundle update is actually retried. I would therefore go for a sleep and retry approach here.

I'm going to apply this patch and do a release. 

@kwin I did comment a bit more on your points on SLING-5457.

@kwin the osgi installer cycle at the end compacts the persistentList in case any Resource is left the next cycle is immediately triggered (return ACTION.CYCLE;) This is why setting to IGNORE breaks the cycle but exiting a TaskResource unhandled causes the next cycle. Just check my IT which covers positive and negative cases and proves that multiple retries happen without any further intervention.

Not sure I can follow here. I see that https://github.com/apache/sling/blob/533d13c2138cce10baa146f11199b1d8d3f99d5d/installer/core/src/main/java/org/apache/sling/installer/core/impl/EntityResourceList.java#L434 only returns `true` in case some resource in the resource group has been uninstalled. Therefore https://github.com/apache/sling/blob/5473afd0196b58d0e0395cf6a98296af0dcc664f/installer/core/src/main/java/org/apache/sling/installer/core/impl/OsgiInstallerImpl.java#L913 should return `false` in your case as well. Not sure why in your IT the according TaskFactory is indeed called multiple times.

If 

> the osgi installer cycle at the end compacts the persistentList in case any Resource is left the next cycle is immediately triggered (return ACTION.CYCLE;) 

would be true, we would have a loop in https://github.com/apache/sling/blob/8317c5d255192113587a1369571fe9ad2b7d8014/installer/factories/packages/src/main/java/org/apache/sling/installer/factory/packages/impl/PackageTransformer.java#L234.

Hm, on second thought I think I agree that this sounds odd. I'll have to look into the it test some more to see if it really captures the right thing because it almost looks like it is not checking enough to be sure it tests what it is supposed to test.
I think you can close this PR (see SLING-5457 for details).
@DominikSuess This has been merged, can you close this PR?
@ieb This has been fixed, can you close this PR?

Please do not include formatting changes with functional pull requests.

As I commented on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING-6655, the methods you are deprecating are used by scripting implementations. They should not be deprecated (or removed).
incorporated in the Sling code base. Closing.

Can you prepare a patch for https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/sling/site/trunk/content/documentation/bundles/models.mdtext as well which explains this change (and in the best case links this JIRA issue)?
closing this one, it's superseded by #203
its applied to svn
linked in jira ticket: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING-6763
@royteeuwen Addressed all your comments and added in the needed RAT excludes. The Sling Models API / IMPL on Sling 8 is 1.2.2, so I used that instead of 1.3.
Cool, looks nice :)!
Patched by @raducotescu in https://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1791224
Applied, thanks!
Manually applied in f82774210cfd523c9e9023274ae3401710b7c305, thanks @JEBailey for the submission!
@JEBailey  - I failed to use a proper commit message, can you manually close this PR now that it's applied?
manually closing per request by @rombert
I've had some conversations, I'm working on an improved status
@kwin done :-)
/cc @chetanmeh if you can sanity check this, would be appreciated.
ticket closed as "won't fix" - see SLING-6826 for details

Added with commit:  2bd37e44f4bbdb0acab8354b960760b7ef3f97a7 

https://github.com/apache/sling/commit/2bd37e44f4bbdb0acab8354b960760b7ef3f97a7
Which versions are exactly affected? We are using 2.11.0. Thank you
From what I can tell, this has been present since mid-2015. I'm not sure what versions that means it affects though.

Looks good to me, thanks! I only have one request - can you update the README file for this module to include the update process using npm and gulp? It will be useful for people less versed in frontend development ( myself included ).
Closing this pull request, will raise fresh pr

@rombert i added a new "improvement" to jira to track
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING-6938
@rombert @royteeuwen i updated the api's as suggested.
(not sure why 8826c6a is included here)
Thanks for the contribuition @AndreeaDieaconu  . Can you also add a Sling jira issue at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING ?
@volteanu, as the patch was applied, can you close this PR?

Hi @dherges .

Well, this is an interesting proposition :-) While I personally believe "fun" is entirely subjective and for me personally Sling is a lot of fun, I you think this is somehow innapropriate please discuss it on our user's mailing list users@sling.apache.org .

I can't close this PR outright due to the way ASF git mirrors are setup, so please close it yourself.

Looking forward to your email.
Your pull request broke the build, it is therefore not fun.  We cannot accept a PR that breaks the build (or the fun.)

Yeah, your joke made my day! 

Cheers, David
